elements.title: Jenny Hurn (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jenny Hurn (pictured) in Lincolnshire, England, is said to be haunted by a boggart that crosses the River Trent in a dish propelled by oars the size of teaspoons?

elements.title: Mount Leona Fire (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the Mount Leona Fire was finally contained on the upper slopes of Profanity Peak?

elements.title: Yang Jingru (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the International Olympic Committee's TikTok account praised the "incredible strategy" of speed skater Yang Jingru's win at the 2024 Winter Youth Olympics?

elements.title: Empire of Death (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that according to writer Russell T Davies, he conceived elements of the Doctor Who episode "Empire of Death" decades before he wrote it?

elements.title: Gerhard Klingenberg (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that during his tenure as the manager of Austria's Burgtheater from 1971 to 1976, Gerhard Klingenberg often directed plays with analogies of a divided Europe?

elements.title: Red (Taylor's Version) (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Red (Taylor's Version) was credited by media publications with popularizing the "Sad Girl Autumn" phenomenon in popular culture?

elements.title: René Heyde (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that 14 months after taking up track cycling, René Heyde only narrowly missed out being selected to the New Zealand team at the 1972 Summer Olympics?

elements.title: 181 Montague Street (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that during the construction of 181 Montague Street in New York City, each of the building's columns was pulled by 14 horses?

elements.title: a shrine to Marmite (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Unilever invited Britons to congregate and worship at a shrine to Marmite in 2010?
